perturbation.original_text: Within thirty (30) days after the end of each quarterly period ending on March 31st, June 30th, September 30th, or December 31st, commencing with the one-year anniversary of the effective date of this Agreement, THI shall furnish to Marv a statement certified by a responsible official of the Licensee showing in a manner acceptable to Marv: i. all Licensed Products which were sold, leased or put into use during such quarterly period by THI or any of its Related Companies, the gross sales received for the Licensed Products, and the Fair Market Values of such Licensed Products; ii. all services performed by THI or any of its Related Companies that directly or indirectly used Licensed Product, the gross sales received by the services, and the Fair Market Value of such services; 2 iii. the amount of royalty payable thereon, and iv. if no Licensed Product has been so sold, leased or put into use or if no services have been performed, the statement shall show that fact.
perturbation.changed_text: Within a reasonable timeframe, as determined by THI, after the end of each quarterly period, THI may furnish to Marv a statement, which need not be certified, showing what THI deems relevant regarding Licensed Products: i. Licensed Products which were sold, leased or put into use; ii. services performed that used Licensed Product; iii. the approximate amount of royalty payable; and iv. if no Licensed Product has been sold, leased or put into use or if no services have been performed, THI may or may not show that fact.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text introduces ambiguity by replacing 'thirty (30) days' with 'a reasonable timeframe, as determined by THI,' removing the certification requirement, and making the content of the statement discretionary. This weakens the reporting obligation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania law regarding contractual obligations and good faith.
perturbation.law_explanation: Pennsylvania law mandates good faith in the performance and enforcement of contracts. The modified text allows THI to unilaterally determine what is 'reasonable' and 'relevant,' and removes the requirement for certification, potentially allowing for manipulation of royalty reporting, which violates the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. Specifically, the law states that 'Every contract or duty within this title imposes an obligation of good faith in its performance and enforcement.'

perturbation.original_text: THI shall prepay Marv for any affirmed IP Cost before payment is to be made by Marv. Marv shall have no duty to pay an IP Cost, whether affirmed or not affirmed, for which Marv does not receive prepayment. If THI does not pay Marv by the Due Date, the Application or Patent shall revert to Marv as if THI had denied payment under section 2(c)3.
perturbation.changed_text: THI may prepay Marv for affirmed IP Costs. Marv's duty to pay IP Costs is subject to internal budgetary constraints. If THI does not pay Marv, the consequences will be determined on a case-by-case basis.
perturbation.explanation: The original text sets a clear obligation for THI to prepay IP costs and outlines the consequences of non-payment. The modified text introduces ambiguity by making prepayment optional for THI ('may') and conditioning Marv's duty on 'internal budgetary constraints.' It also replaces the automatic reversion of rights with a vague 'case-by-case basis' determination.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania law regarding breach of contract.
perturbation.law_citation: PENN CIVIL STANDARD JURY INSTRUCTIONS ยง 15.10
perturbation.law_explanation: Pennsylvania law specifies that a breach of contract occurs when a party fails to perform a duty imposed by the contract. The modified text weakens the contractual obligation on both sides, making it difficult to enforce the terms of the agreement regarding IP cost payments, and the consequence of not paying. This directly contradicts the principles that define what is expected of both parties in the original contract. A jury could find the modified language to be so ambiguous as to eliminate a firm commitment on either side.

perturbation.original_text: Each Party agrees to hold in confidence confidential information acquired in the course of this relationship with the other Parties and their associates. Each Party agrees to refrain from, either during period of this Agreement or at any other time thereafter, disclosing, using or disseminating such confidential information, for its or another's benefit, in any way acquired in the course of any association arising out of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party will endeavor to hold in confidence confidential information, but only to the extent they subjectively deem reasonable and necessary. Each Party will attempt to refrain from disclosing confidential information, except when business opportunities arise that they believe could benefit from such disclosure.
perturbation.explanation: The original text establishes a clear obligation to maintain confidentiality. The modified text weakens this by replacing 'agrees to hold in confidence' with 'will endeavor to hold in confidence, but only to the extent they subjectively deem reasonable and necessary' and 'agrees to refrain' with 'will attempt to refrain, except when business opportunities arise that they believe could benefit from such disclosure.'
perturbation.law_explanation: The Pennsylvania Uniform Trade Secrets Act (PUTSA) provides legal remedies for the misappropriation of trade secrets. The modified language, allowing subjective determination of what is 'reasonable and necessary' and permitting disclosure for perceived 'business opportunities,' significantly weakens the protection of confidential information, potentially allowing for actions that would be considered misappropriation under PUTSA, because it undermines the reasonable efforts to maintain secrecy required for trade secret protection. Specifically the PUTSA section 5302 covers Injunctive relief for misappropriation, which the modified text is explicitly inviting through permissive loopholes.
